ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] more than one representation with the same MIME type

From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
>
> We should be proliferating mimetypes.
> Their purpose is to represent different document
> expectations.
> We should use them that way!

That would be nice, but the practice seems somewhat different than theory
here.

For instance, there is no way for a server to know which version of HTML to
return based on the content-type.  Should the HTML be strictly 3.2 or should
it be 4.0?  Using "text/html" is not enough.  Using the user-agent (which is
probably the most common technique) it just plain wrong.  A server can't
possibly know every user-agent out there and shouldn't even care.  To avoid
this, sites are left to tactics like home pages that have a low-end home
page with links to the rest of the site in different version.  Hardly a good
solution.

The same could be said for distinguishing between RSS 0.91, 0.92, 0.93, and
2.0 (along with any other generic xml) since all that's used is "text/xml".
Using "text/rss+xml" wouldn't be enough either.  In my blog system, if it
gets "Accept:text/xml", it return RSS 2.0.  In order to get any other
version, you have to resort to a kludge (in this case using a query string
indicating the specific version).  This is just plain wrong and should not
be how it has to be done...

Now, maybe if people got into the habit of using a "version" parameter in
mime types, this could be avoided(?).  For instance, it would be no problem
to determine what a request means by "Accept:text/rss+xml;version=0.92".  I
realize you could just register something like "text/rss092+xml", but the
parameter is somewhat extensible without the need to register each new
version.  As is done with the xhtml "profile" parameter, it may even make
sense to use a URI instead of a simple version number.  This obviously has
tradeoffs, of course.

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...
